p.i: The stone walls of this area seem to have been built around the same time as the buildings above. There are scuffs in the dirt floor that indicate large boxes have been moved around the space frequently. Along the walls, wooden crates are stacked bearing a logo of a cat eye with “Smiling Sundries” stenciled on them in common. To the north and east are metal doors, and to the south is a wooden door with a sign that says ‘CAUTION: NO ENTRY’ in common as well as a set of stairs leading up.

text.p: This section of the underground sits directly beneath the store house. It is used by the sundries shop as overflow stock storage.
The crates in the room are filled with 3d100GP worth of various adventuring gear and shelf-stable rations. They can be opened with the help of a crowbar.

p.i: This room is filled with large wooden barrels labelled as mead, ale and beer. A ladder in the center of the room ascends to a hatch in the wooden ceiling.

text.p: The connecting room to the main storage area is used by the tavern to store extra drink casks. The hatch in the ceiling leads to the tavern’s pantry. The door opens inward and is blocked from the inside by heavy full casks, which need to be moved before the DC20 locked door can be opened. The key for this door is on the keyrings held by the bar staff and the sundries shop owner.
It looks like someone began to remove dirt here to create a new basement but never finished - the walls and floor are loose dirt and stones.

There is a pick axe and a bag containing dynamite and a key to area B in this area, in a small tunnel in the Northeast corner. The tight tunnel leading to it is unstable and will collapse if not navigated carefully, trapping anyone in the tunnel underneath.

p.i: This area seems to have been modified from a naturally occuring cave - the walls are uneven, and shadowy cracks and crevices lead to small dark holes that light refuses to reach. Strewn around the floor are discarded bones, hair, feces and scraps of fabric, suffusing the air with an unnerving putrescence. The muffled sound of squeaking comes from all around.

text.p: These caves are blocked off behind a DC20 locked metal door. The only key to this area is in area A3. The holes in the wall and ceiling of this area have become home to a large nest

This cave splits into left and right paths. The walls here are dotted with rat nest holes, and a mix of regular and mutated giant rats are hiding in them. If the party aggravates the rat swarms in the weapon cache room, they will come out of their holes and attack the party. Investigating the holes will reveal the encounter loot.

p.i: Before it was overrun with rats, this area seems to have been a weapons cache. The metal racks and hooks on the walls are now empty. A wooden bench with a knife and morning star resting on it is all that’s left in the room.

text.p: The rats have made this cave their nest, they occupy a cluttered pile of rusted metal and scraps of wood and fabric. The nest on the floor of this area is difficult terrain.

Upon someone disturbing their nest, the rats will swarm and attack the intruders. Once any of them reach half health, they will begin squealing loudly, alerting the rest of the rats in the area, who will begin to pour out of the holes in the walls of the cave. The rats will continue to fight until they are killed off.
The only weapons left in this area are a rusted old dagger and a mageforged morning star on the bench. Moving into the room to obtain the weapons will aggravate the rats.

Mageforged weapons are crafted in a way that allows them to store a spell. A magic caster can impart any prepared attack spell on the weapon, expending one of their spell slots to transfer the spell to the weapon. The spell can then be used at the owner’s will as an effect of a melee attack. Any damage and conditions of the spell stack with the weapon damage.
The rusted old dagger is actually a vicious dagger, however its special properties are unusable until it has been restored by a smith.

The sounds of creaking wood, footsteps, and muffled voices emanate from the cobwebbed wooden ceiling here. Occasionally you can hear what sound like shouts and cheers. A thick layer of dirt coats the walls and floor, obscuring the stonework. Cracks of light project down from above and lace the ground, capturing motes of floating dust.

This area is directly beneath the tavern’s first floor, and the sounds of the patrons above carry down through the floorboards. The eastern half of the space is being used as a storage and tinkering area by the smugglers, and the west chamber has been left abandoned due to its proximity to the giant spider’s web.
The wooden ceiling of this room is barely 7 feet high. Dark tunnels lead off from it to the North and Northwest, and in the Southeast, dim lantern light flickers from around a corner.
The ceiling of this room is only six and a half feet high, and there are a large number of cobwebs crisscrossing it.

A sleeping Kobold guard named Kiki is leaning against the wall of the Southeast tunnel - they’re supposed to be keeping watch for rats and the spider. The Kobold can be snuck past with a DC10 stealth check, but if awakened will alert the other Kobolds in the adjacent areas C2 and D.

There is a 5x5x10 foot hidden pit trap in this room at the entrance to the Northwest tunnel, disguised to match the material of the surrounding floor. The trap is rigged with bells, and setting off the trap will awaken the nearby sleeping Kobold guard. The sides of the pit are greased and require a DC20 Dexterity check to climb.

p.i: Sounds of clanking and Kobolds chattering echo from the north side of this room. They are bent over two open crates, comparing discarded components and pieces of junk. Strewn about the room are various strange contraptions that seem to approximate machines.

text.p: This room has been co-opted by a pair of Kobold Inventors named Brik and Brak as a tinkering space. They are preoccupied with two crates full of various odds and ends, and won’t notice anyone sneaking past them through the southern end of the room. However, they will come to assist if the Kobolds in areas C1 or D raise an alert. If spied upon, they will be discussing various ideas for traps to place in the area, and may mention one of the monsters occupying the underground smuggling tunnels.

The inventors have a variety of small throwable traps strapped to their bodies, as well as laying about the space. When a player moves into a new square in the north part of the room, there is a 1d8 chance that they will inadvertently set off one of the traps they have left lying out on the ground (DEX 15 save to avoid the effects)

p.i: The wall here has crumbled away, creating a breach between the earth tunnel and a stone lined sewer.

text.p: This tunnel intersects with the sewer built into the base of the wall, area G. The rubble spills over into the area and acts as difficult terrain in the 10 feet surrounding the entrance.
This entrance to the sewer is guarded by the giant spider whose web fills the tunnel. Occasionally, a rat will wander in here from the sewer or area B, and their carcasses hang in the webs.
The tunnel leading North to this exit is filled with webs. A giant spider lives here and attempts to trap any creatures that come through this tunnel.

The Kobolds are aware of the spider (it caught and ate one) so will avoid following intruders into this tunnel. Occasionally rats will enter the tunnel, their carcasses are hanging from the walls and ceiling. The spider will hide in wait (DC20 to notice it) and will only attack once a creature has entered the tunnel. The webs here count as difficult terrain. Setting fire to the webs will quickly burn them, and flush the spider out of the tunnel whichever direction is away from the blaze. The spider can also be distracted with carcasses of fallen rats and kobolds from the area.
The unmistakable scent of Kobolds fills this area. Dirty cloth bedrolls lay out of the floor and burnt candle nubs litter the corners.

This room serves the smugglers as a base of operations on the south side of the wall. At any given time there are 4 Kobolds in this area, either sleeping, eating, or sorting contraband that they are in the process of transporting through the tunnels. They will defend themselves from any intruders that find their way down, calling the other Kobolds in the area. If it becomes obvious that they are outmatched, they will attempt to escape via area D1, and flee to the sub-basement though area H2.
The Kobolds have stored their loot in sacks near their sleeping area.
This section of the wall has been excavated to form a connection with the drains under the bath house, and is the main way that the Kobolds enter and exit the area.

A Kobold is always on guard in this area, watching the Northwest and East entrances to the area. It takes a DC20 stealth check to gain surprise on them. When the party enters the area, Drak the Kobold will be on duty. He is paranoid, and reacts immediately to any suspicious noises or flickers of shadow.

3 Kobolds are in this area, resting. There is a 1D4 chance that each of them is asleep. If so, they will begin an encounter surprised. The Kobolds in this area will attempt to defend themselves first, and stop the party from nearing or entering the stash room secondly.

Krag, Dirk, and Bok are in this area at the time that the party enters. Krag is a larger, more aggressive kobold than the others, and often bullies them. He is also more likely to fight to the death with any intruders, and when bloodied he flies into a rage and gains a +2 advantage on melee attacks and 5 temporary hit points. Bok is a coward and will avoid fighting up close if possible, putting the others in between him and an enemy. Dirk is surprisingly agile, and has a natural +2 advantage on dexterity checks, ranged attacks and AC. He enjoys taunting his foes from a distance but will surrender if cornered.

p.i: The walls and ceiling of this excavated dirt room are supported with dubious looking wooden slats. And boards. It is devoid of any furnishings with the exception of a large wooden chest and a lantern.
Effect | Drops 2 centipede swarms from the ceiling

text.p: The DC20 locked chest in this area contains the contraband that the smugglers are currently moving. Attempting to open the chest without first disarming the trap will trigger its effect. It is filled with 10d100GP worth of Basilisk Blood in small crystal vials. It also contains instructions for delivery of the drugs to the buyer. The key to the chest is on the Kobold Guard in area D2.

Basilisk Blood is a powerful sedative. Often used to numb pain for surgery, it is extremely popular recreationally as well due to its addictive nature. One dose completely removes all sensation of pain in the body, as well as creating a euphoric emotion in the user. It grants 1d6 temporary hit points and the user temporarily ignores being fatigued, frightened, stunned or exhausted.

After taking a dose, the user can move and act normally for another hour, enduring even debilitating pain. Afterwards they proceed to fall into a deep sleep for the following 4 hours, during which time it is almost impossible to wake them.

Every time a user takes this drug they run a 1d4 risk of becoming addicted. If a dose of Basilisk Blood isn't consumed once per day by an addict, they are afflicted with level 3 exhaustion (Disadvantage on ability checks, speed halved, disadvantage on attack rolls and saving throws). An addiction can only be cured via magical means.

The drug is available in the Dragon States through exotic medicine sellers, at high price. It is outright banned within the Fey Dominion because of its impure nature. Nonetheless, the demand for it makes it a hot commodity on the smuggling market.

The Kobold smugglers have contracted with a Dominion black market dealer known as Quell. In the note, they have instructed the Kobolds to have the shipment ready for pickup at the dropoff point the following night at 10PM. Anyone trained in Thieves Cant will be able to identify the authenticity of the note. Quell’s name is known in the underground circles of the dragonside of the city as a dealer who is open to working with even the lowliest levels of criminals, up to and including rogue Kobolds.

p.i: These pipes are cramped and narrow, and coated with a thick layer of grime and mildew that sloughs off on anything that touches it. Water trickles down from rows of drain pipes in the ceiling. There is a muted sound of running water.

text.p: These drains service the bath house above. In the center of the intersecting cross there is an opening on the ceiling leading up to the broken tub. A rope hangs down, allowing someone to climb and get out with a DC10 strength check to move the wooden tub. The drains are just large enough for a medium size creature to squeeze through.

This is the main entrance that the Kobolds have been using to access the underground. A check of the area will reveal their footprints and claw marks throughout the area, and their soiled feet track mildew out into their den as well as into the sewer.

At any given time there is a 1d8 chance that the Kobold on guard in the adjacent area might come to patrol these pipes. If they encounter an intruder, they will attempt to run back to their den to alert the other Kobolds stationed there. The Kobolds will avoid fighting in this area if possible due to it’s constriction, but might block the party inside to force them into a disadvantage.
This section of the wall has been excavated to form a connection with the smuggler’s den in area D, and is the main way that the Kobolds enter and exit the area.

The pipe here bends up 90 degrees and continues straight up, where it connects with the floor drain in the tavern kitchen. It is just big enough for a small size creature to shimmy up and down. The pipe is climbable with a DC 15 dexterity check by anyone able to fit down it, however size medium and larger creatures cannot fit through it.

The kobolds have been using this pipe to steal food from the tavern food store in the Kitchen above, which they eat themselves as well as use to distract the Gelatinous Cube in the adjacent sewer tunnel. Inspection of the pipe will reveal their claw marks on the walls. The grate at the top is unscrewed and lifts off easily.

Smiling dropped her earring down one of the bathtub drain above. It is made of Pewter and has an ornament in the shape of a tiny bell on it. When worn, it grants a +4 to perception checks related to hearing. It is worth 320GP, or 400GP at Smiling Sundries (Southwall, area F).

p.i: This sewer appears to be crafted of the same type of stone as the Border Wall above. It runs straight, at a nearly imperceptible grade. Currently the water is only flowing a half inch deep. The walls, floor and low ceiling here look surprisingly clean, though somewhat slimy.

text.p: The sewer is built into the base of the wall, and is designed to remove waste water as well as reroute flood waters to the bay. This section has been breached on both sides, and has created a passthrough underneath the wall.

A young Gelatinous Cube has made its way into this stretch and has grown to the width of the sewer tunnel. It is not fully developed yet: it is only 5 feet to a side, moves at a rate of 10 feet per turn, and only does half damage when it attacks.

The cube will methodically chase any living creature that enters the tunnel, but can easily be distracted with food. It normally dwells around the Eastern end of the tunnel in between the two drain entrances, and the Kobolds have taken to using it as a sort of security door for their route. They use food stolen from the kitchen above to lure the cube down the tunnel, and then cross to the pipes on the other side.

The grates at either end of the sewer tunnel are sunk directly into the stonework and are solid steel. They require a full day’s worth of work with filing tools to dismantle. The grate bars are too close together for small creatures or larger to fit through. If anyone breaks through and traverses further into the sewers, they will find nothing of note and after a half mile of trekking will eventually find a storm drain with a metal rung ladder leading up to a random place aboveground.

Rubble spills over into the area from the tunnel leading to area C and acts as difficult terrain in the 10 feet surrounding the entrance. There are wisps of spider silk clinging to the area around this tunnel entrance.
See area C3 for information about the giant spider in the tunnel.

The pipe widens at the mouth and opens into the sewer here. This opening is too small for the Gelatinous Cube in the sewer to enter. Scrawled on the wall in poorly written Draconic is the word “Feed”, an instruction to use food to move the cube.

On the opposite side of the sewer from the basement, a second drain pipe runs north. The drain is just large enough for a medium sized creature to squeeze through. The Gelatinous Cube cannot fit into this opening.
The kobolds use this drain to access the lower portion of the underground route. There are marks on the floor and walls that indicate their movement through the area (DC10 perception to notice).

p.i: A narrow pipe, just wide enough to squeeze through, connects perpendicular to the main sewer here. There seems to be a slight upward grade to it and seems to connect to several more offshoots.

text.p: This section of the drains is designed to siphon overflow from the main sewer. It inclines gradually and is currently completely dry.

p.i: The walls of this section of pipe are uncomfortably tight around your arms, and force you to worm your way further. Something glimmers at the end in a pile of rubbish.
Effect | Pinned until save is made

text.p: This dead end acts like a trap, getting gradually tighter until anyone of small size or larger becomes stuck with their arms and legs pinned to their sides. Anyone who attempts to help someone trapped in this pipe also risks becoming trapped as well. The glimmer at the end is just from a piece of scrap metal.

p.i: The drain opens up here into a wider bell-shaped space. In the middle of the floor a large metal grate has rusted through, exposing an opening to a yawning dark shaft below. Cool damp air blows up through it. A worn looking braided hemp rope is tied off at the top to one of the rusted grate bars, and trails down the shaft into shadow.

text.p: This drain leads down to the overflow cistern 30 feet below. The kobolds have tied off a rope here, and use it to move up and down between the areas. Upon closer inspection, it is badly frayed. Anyone of size medium or larger attempting to use the rope runs a 1d4 risk of it snapping under their weight and dropping them down the shaft.

If investigated with a light source, the cistern full of water below is visible. Dropping anything down to disturb the water will alert the Water Weird in the cistern to intruders. Falling into the water does not cause damage, but will initiate an encounter with the elemental.
Kobold prints and claw marks are visible throughout this room. Scrawled on the wall in poorly written Draconic are the words “Bad Water”, a warning about the elemental in the cistern below.

If the Kobolds from area D surrender to the party, they will lead them to this area under the promise of showing them the north exit of the tunnels. They will attempt to get the party to go down the rope first, and if successful they will then cut the rope, dropping whoever’s descending it directly into the pool below to encounter the awaiting water weird.

p.i: Our story opens in the common room of The Grinning Gander, a busy tavern in the shadow of the Drostellan border wall.

It's 7PM and the crowd inside the taproom is starting to get dense. A travelling elf bard going by the name "Summer Wind" is crooning to the gathered patrons, using magic to amplify his voice and float orbs of light out above the crowd for ambiance. The innkeeper gnome dodges between the legs of patrons and chairs to deliver drinks. Behind the bar, the orc bartender keeps the ale flowing. And, in the back corner of the room, a small group forms.

You’ve been assembled here at the request of a mutual acquaintance. The man sitting across from you at the table is Randal Reyne, veteran member of The Rising and coordinator for Resistance operations in Dragonside. His reason for convening you: to assign you your first mission for the cause.

text.p: Once a quaint inn, The Grinning Gander is now notorious as a hotbed for rougher types. The current innkeeper is more interested in gambling, drinking games and general debauchery than he is in the upkeep of his inherited family business. Likewise, the patrons and staff both are on the seedier side, though generally good natured. This makes it the perfect location for resistance operatives to meet without the threat of discovery, as the volume and general chaos of the bar provide a level of anonymity.

Unknown to the bar staff, several entrances to the underground smuggling route are scattered across the property. Randal informs the party that his intel has isolated this block as the site of the tunnel, and their group has been chosen for an practical test of their skills in finding and securing the route. He says that they will be observed, and if successful they will be graduated to full members of the local Resistance branch.

p.i: The bar is crowded and loud, as Lelhallan is a commonly observed holiday for drunken celebration. All sorts of people are packed in, laughing and carousing. Getting space at the bar might be hard unless you are patient, or else shove through the crowd.

text.p: Behind the bar, an Orc bartender is serving drinks. Xugha Redbleeder is a large brutish figure with an imposing attitude, but his friend Zane Farlight, an obnoxious human barfly who always hangs out with him during his shifts, will attempt to get one or more of the party to bet on a game of cups with Xugha. Fortunately for them, he is poor at sleight of hand, and it’s fairly easy to win against him.

If Xugha loses as a game Zane will continue to egg the betters on, until 3 successful tries. At that point Xugha will be tapped out and throw his money pouch at the players in frustration. Inside the pouch are the winnings as well as the keys to the pantry and store house. If the party chooses to keep the keys, Xugha won’t notice them missing until after his shift ends. However if they choose to return them they will win his favor and he will provide information about the Kobold smugglers.

Summer Wind is singing for the crowded taproom. A classically trained Elven bard, he considers this venue below his station - but an addiction to basilisk blood has caused him to fall on hard times. If the party engages with him between sets, he can be persuaded into talking to Fey members of the group but will likely ignore non-Fey. Upon entering a conversation with him he will have nothing of importance to say about the smuggling operation but will openly ask about them procuring him his drug of choice. If they can provide it to him he is more than willing to pay them for their troubles.

Podon Felhim, the Gnome innkeeper, is working the seating area as a server. While normally acting as the proprietor of the lodging side of the business, the Inn’s bad reputation has led to a dip in guests, and so he is now having to make up the difference with entertainment and service. He booked Summer Wind at great expense in an effort to drum up sales for the holiday.

While he has the businesses best interests at heart, his love of gambling and unseemly friends have led to a falling out between him and his mother, who used to be the innkeeper but now runs the bath house next door.

Podon is partial to games of skill, and is trying to organize competitions to drum up more business. If a character with a higher than average strength score approaches him, he will invite them to go upstairs and test their skills against the reigning armwrestling champion with Zuri. If they have a higher than average constitution score, he will send them to start a drinking competition with Earthbreaker. Otherwise, he will point them to a game of cards happening on the ground floor.
Podon carries a duplicate set of storage keys to the ones that Xugha has, but they are on his person and will need to be pickpocketed or otherwise stolen from him.

p.i: This room stores extra bottles and ingredients for the bar. A hatch that leads down to the Tavern’s Cask Cellar is set into the floor, and on the ceiling is a rope winch for moving casks up and down.

text.p: There is 450 GP worth of alcohol stored in bottles in this storage room, as well as various serving vessels and popular mixed drink ingredients.
The door to this room is locked with one of the storage keys held by the innkeeper and bartender. Sneaking into this room would be hard because it is in full visibility of the crowded bar.

This elevated loft wraps around the second floor of the inn, and is dimly lit with candles. This area overlooks the open first floor and many patrons crowd up here to drink and listen to the performance happening below.

In one corner, a crowd forms around Juri Rustmail, the local champion arm wrestler. She is a Dwarf trapper from The Deep that comes to town to sell off rare and exotic monster parts to arcane merchants. Her favorite activity is using her prowess with strength competitions to win money.

The party can engage her directly or at the suggestion of the innkeeper. She is competitive but jovial and friendly, and if they win she will congratulate them and offer them a deal: she is currently hunting for water elementals in order to harvest their nucleus to sell. If the party finds one and brings it to her, she will trade them for a “fancy Dwarf treasure.”

Earthbreaker, a goliath soldier, draws a crowd in the opposite corner. A member of the city guard, he is well known as a competitive drinker in his off time. He is boisterous, and openly challenges anyone who dares to try out-drinking him. However, he doesn’t have much coin left after purchasing his drinks, and if he loses he will refuse to give the party any winnings.

Further engagement with him (or refusing to hand over their gold after losing to him) will cause Earthbreaker to attempt to begin a bar fight with his challenger. If this happens there is a 1d6 chance every round that the rest of the party will get sucked into an all-out bar brawl with whoever else is surrounding them. If the fight goes on too long, constables will show up at the bar and stop the fight, arresting whoever’s involved.

p.i: These rented rooms are currently empty during the bar crawl hours of the evening. Noise from the common area seeps under the doors. They are sparsely outfitted with functional look beds and lockable storage chests.

text.p: There is a 1d4 chance that each room is currently rented out. If it is, the storage chest is locked with a DC15 lock. Roll on a random loot table for the contents.

The party begins this mission convening with one another for the first time as a splinter group. They are introduced to each other by a mutually trusted member of the Resistance - Randal Reyne, who serves as a private guard to a Dragonborn emissary for the Gilt Wyrm. Randal is a veteran of the local branch of The Rising, and is a coordinator for recruiting new members to the resistance efforts in Drostella. An avid reader and writer, Randal is educated beyond his station as a guard. The child of an escaped Dominion slave, he joined the resistance in his early 20’s and has been active in numerous missions with the help of many factions. He is well known and liked within the community, with a reputation for always having something encouraging to say.

Before the start of the mission, each member of the team receives an individualized summons from Randal, asking them to meet him on the evening of Lelhallan (a major celebration in the Fey religious calendar) at The Grinning Gander, a tavern in Southwall. There, he says that they will be introduced to their new team and assigned their first official mission.

p.i: The chirping of crickets is audible in this small outdoor plot. It is bordered on all sides by buildings - to the north is the border wall, east is the back of the tavern, south is a squat looking stone building with a metal door, and west is the back of a private home with shuttered windows. There is a low wooden bench out here, and an old well stands in the corner.

text.p: This courtyard serves as an overflow area for the bar crowd. It is dimly illuminated by a few lanterns and there are deep shadows in the corners.

The well in the corner has come to serve as a urinal for the bar patrons, and if inspected smells somewhat foul of urine. There is nothing of particular interest in the bottom of the well, except a handful of wet copper coins and an annoyed non-monstrous rat that will attack anyone who tries to enter its nest.
This heavy metal door leads into the storehouse, and is locked with a DC20 lock. The bartender and innkeeper both have a copy of the key needed to unlock it.

p.i: This kitchen is filled with the smells of frying meat and stew. “Aw, fuck, damn… HOLD UP IT’S ALMOST READY!” A young human cook frantically runs between the prep tables, assembling dishes to serve the bar customers while muttering under his breath.

text.p: Gregory Twoorb, the one and only chef at The Grinning Gander, runs this kitchen in a state of organized chaos. Half finished meals are strewn across the tables here, and several large pots bubble on the hearth. He is in the middle of a dinner rush and doesn’t have much time at all to talk to the party if they try to interrupt him. But, if they pester him long enough he will reveal that he is currently trying to catch a “band of bandits” that keep breaking into the kitchen to steal groceries, and points them to the food stores.

This large shelving unit is filled with different meal ingredients, everything from meat cuts and vegetables to spices and oils. However there are some conspicuously empty shelves near the bottom. Upon closer inspection, the party will notice some distinctive scratch marks that may be identified as Kobold marks with a skilled check.

This drain is set into the tile floor and is big enough to be squeezed through by a small sized creature. Closer inspection will reveal that the screws on it are loosened, allowing for the grate cover to be lifted and removed.
This hole connects to the secret tunnels that the Kobolds have been using to smuggle goods through the bath house, and they have been coming up through it to steal food for their secret base below.

p.i: A humid waft of air envelops you as soon as you step into this dimly lit building. The sound of running water emanates from several of the curtained stalls lined up against the walls, and it smells of soap. An elderly, disagreeable looking Gnome woman sits on a stool at the entrance. She squints at you and barks “Five copper for a bath, and a silver for soap. Bring your own towel. And - no belts! They’ve been banned.”

text.p: This bath house is run by Tamyra Felhim, the elderly mother of the innkeeper next door. She has had a falling out with her son and has now disowned the inn, instead choosing to run this public bathing facility.
She is cranky by default, though mainly just tired and disengaged. Being severely nearsighted, she hasn’t even noticed that the Kobold smugglers have been using her business as a smuggling route.

Recently, her prized locket containing a portrait of her and her son as a baby went missing. If the party rounds the corner of the block and investigates the back alley behind the bath house, they will find a crow that has been playing with the locket. Upon scaring off the crow they can retrieve it and return it to her to gain her favor. She will then tell them about the large number of “rude and smelly” kobolds that have been using her baths recently.
The bath itself has seen better days. The stalls are dilapidated and some of the faucets don’t seem to work. A mild mildew odor permeates the stalls.

There is a rack for hanging and drying clothes near the entrance as well as some wash tubs for doing laundry. If the party checks the clothing, roll on the random loot table to see what they find in the pockets.

This tub is visibly busted, with a sign reading “OUT OF ORDER” in common hanging from the stall curtain. Upon closer inspection the party will notice that a hole is concealed under the tub base. The hole is large enough for a medium sized creature to squeeze through, and leads down to the area under the bath house.

This is the secret entrance that the smugglers have been using to gain entrance to the underground. If the characters stake out the location, there is a 1d4 chance every hour that they will observe a Kobold entering or leaving the hole discreetly.

p.i: The inner perimeter of this reinforced building is lined with locked steel storage cages. Inside you can see chests, barrels and crates marked with the names of various companies in the neighborhood. The stone walls and floors show the scrapes and scuffs of a busy warehouse. In the center of the building, another metal door seems to lead to an inner vault.

text.p: This communal storehouse services the needs of the Southwall businesses. If the players sneak into this space there is a 1d4 chance that they encounter the miller from Area H lugging his meal inside to store it. He will attempt to identify who they are if he catches them, and if he realizes they are intruders he will run out the front of the building to alert the authorities.
These metal cages are eached secured with a DC15 padlock. The lockers that are currently in use each have 3d100 GP worth of trade goods stashed in them.

This door is secured from the outside with a DC20 lock. The only key is held by the sundries shopkeeper. The lock is charmed with a tamper alarm: if anyone attempts to unlock the door with a means other than the key without first disarming the spell it will create a loud ringing noise, alerting the shopkeeper as well as anyone else in the vicinity of the store house. The door is only able to be locked or unlocked from the outside.

p.i: Inside of this room, boxes labeled with the words “Smiling Sundries”, the name of the sundries shop next door have been piled high. Some random odds and ends are scattered around, and a set of stairs leads down into the floor.

text.p: This vault is used exclusively by the sundries shop next door. The wooden stairs here lead down to the basement in area A1. There are some miscellaneous adventuring supplies scattered around the room, as well as 2D100 worth of trade goods and an open chest filled with 540GP worth of coins, belonging to the shopkeeper.

This inner room is not visited as frequently as the storage lockers outside, and if the party is able to enter it without setting off the alarm they can spend an extended rest here without being disturbed.

p.i: This shop is filled to the brim with a strange assortment of tools, adventuring gear, weapons, books and other odds and ends. Dubious looking plate mail looms in the corners and on the floor an enormous bear pelt is spread out. The shopkeeper, a Tabaxi with striking spotted yellow fur, saunters about her store, shuffling and primping her wares.

text.p: This general store is owned by Smiling In The Face Of Death, a female Tabaxi merchant. Smiling is an odd creature, though she is well meaning. If the party shows any interest at all in her wares she will go off on a long, distracted tangent about the item, eventually drifting into non sequiturs. She is also quick to tell the party about a large shipment of fish she is receiving for unclear reasons, attempting to persuade them to place an advance order for some. Smiling has storage keys for the inner vault of the storage facility next door. She won’t willingly part with them, but will leave them unattended at the cashiers table if she is distracted by a customer.

linklist.link: Smiling In The Face Of Death

text.p: This table is the point of sale for the shop. A small bag of change is out on the table, and underneath is a DC15 locked chest containing 1D100 GP worth of mixed coins. The key to the chest is on the same ring as the other shop keys.
This metal door is locked with a DC15 lock, the key for it is on Smiling’s keyring. Smiling will notice anyone attempting to unlock the door unless distracted somewhere else in the shop.

This shelf is stocked with spell scrolls that ostensibly do what they’re labeled with. In reality they are poorly transcribed and have a 1d6 chance of being a dud. Several of them actually do something different than they are labeled.If asked about any of the scrolls on the shelf, Smiling will go on a long winded tangent about it.

A cloying mix of smoke scents wreaths the interior of this small shop. Across a large wooden table a young goblin woman sits filing her nails. “Whatchya afta?” She drawls as she finally looks up to notice you. “We got blends of everything fresh in stock yestaday. Good shit right hea.”
This small store sells mixtures of special herbs that, when inhaled as smoke, can provide temporary buffs to natural abilities. They also stock a wide variety of pipes.

Each blend is good for 3 uses. When someone inhales the smoke, their base ability scores associated with the blend will be increased and decreased by 1 point respectively for the following 2 hours. All associated scores and modifiers to the stats will also be temporarily changed. Buffs will stack (both positive and negative) with the exception that the same blend cannot be stacked with itself.

For every use of a particular blend after the first time a player uses it in the span of a month, there is a cumulative 1D8 chance that they become addicted (on a roll of 1 through 3 the third time, 1 through 6 the sixth time, etc…) If a user is currently addicted, they will need to use the blend constantly or else suffer a -2 penalty to the buffed score associated with that blend. Addiction penalties stack the same as buffs. A user can make a constitution saving throw with disadvantage once per day to overcome their addiction; alternatively they can be cured with cure disease.

Agna, the goblin shopkeeper, is bored and will try to gossip with the players if they choose to engage her. She has a crush on the Orc bartender Xugha, and will talk about the “beefcake” next door that she wants a date with. However she dislikes Zane and will discuss how he is desperate for attention and easy to manipulate.

p.i: The curb of the busy street bells out here at the entrance to this stone building. To the left of the entrance, a scrawny old Kobold clangs a wooden ladle against a large metal cauldron, hawking slurry to passerby. On the right, a cart full of milled grain is parked.

text.p: This is the front entrance to the store house. The door is currently unlocked, as a miller is moving his wares into the building. If the party returns later, it is locked with a DC15 lock that can be opened with the keys held by the tavern employees and the shopkeeper.

p.i: “SLUUUUURRRR-RY! SLUUUURRRRR-RY” Squawks the Kobold as his bubbling mixture . “EAAT! GOOOD!”

text.p: A Kobold named Krik is selling slurry (a dish popular with Draconic creatures) by the side of the road here for 2CP a cup. He doesn’t have a sense of taste, and anyone who eats the slurry must make a CON saving throw against regurgitating it due to the rancid flavor.

Krik is secretly a member of the smugglers that are running operations in the underground tunnels. Their slurry stand is a cover to keep watch on the surface. If successfully persuaded (bribed) or intimidated (threatened) they will offer information about the entrance to the tunnels hidden in the bath house. However they will not reveal anything related to the particulars of their plans. If the party attempts to engage with combat, they will throw their ladle at the nearest enemy and attempt to flee.

A half orc miller named Hern Volster is currently lugging his wares off this cart and into the storehouse via the front entrance. Hern is tired from a long work day and won’t pay much attention to anyone outside the entrance to the building, however he will attempt to run off anyone who tampers with his cart.

p.i: Well worn wheel ruts in the cobblestone street lead up to the entrance of this cul-de-sac. To the Northwest, the open doors of The Grinning Gander stream light and laughter out into the evening. To the Northeast stands a dilapidated looking building with a sign showing a bucket and scrub brush, indicating that it is a public bath house. A small smoke shop occupies the Southwest corner, and the West side is framed in by a stately looking moneychanger’s office.

text.p: This area leads to the main entrance of the tavern and the neighboring businesses. A good number of people come and go through this area - if the party spends enough time observing the flow of traffic they will see people of various types coming and going from the bar, as well as a few entering and leaving the other establishments. There is a 1d8 chance they will see a Kobold smuggler carrying a suspicious looking bundle in or out of the bath house.

p.i: Finely crafted mahogany floors and luxurious wallpaper adorn this lofty office. Plants, leather bound books and curios adorn the North and South walls. In the middle of the room at a polished wood desk sits a distinguished looking Dwarf. His beard and mustache are intricately braided brass coils. “Hmmm yes, and how might I help you today?” He says as he stands up to greet you. “Looking for a change of coin?”

text.p: This office is the business place of Umibol Bottlebringer, a money changer. Umibol services merchants and traders looking to exchange coinage in the Trade District. He is quite successful in his profession and will be cordial with any party members who look like they may potentially have finances matching his usual clientele. If questioned, he will complain about the Kobolds frequenting the bath house next door. He doesn’t trust them to be above-board, and will encourage the party to investigate them and potentially remove them as a pest.

p.i: A placid pool of dark water fills the cistern in the middle of this cross-shaped room. It is framed in by four columns supporting the vaulted ceiling, in the center of which is a dark shaft going directly up. Along the walls and cistern wall runs a painted plaster frieze, depicting bas-relief hands raising up to touch a stylized band of flames.

text.p: The pool in this room acts as an overflow for the sewers above. The ridge of the cistern is 3 feet high, and the water level is 1 foot below floor level. The water is 20 feet deep. At the bottom of the cistern is a metal shutter used to drain the water. A metal level that operates the shutter is installed on the east column, facing towards the wall. The level is rusted, and requires a DC20 strength check to move. If it is flipped, the water level will go down by 3 feet per round.

The cistern has become home to a Water Weird, a type of elemental monster usually confined to The Deep. The elemental is bound to the water here, and will attack anyone who disturbs it. The Kobolds have learned how to climb and descend the shaft here without touching the water and have left the elemental alone. The elemental will fight until it is brought to 0 HP, or else when the water has been completely drained from the cistern. The elemental’s nucleus, a round orb of clear jelly-like substance with a blue gem at the center, is prized as an arcane ingredient. If the cistern is drained, it will be sucked out with the rest of the water. Otherwise, it will float on the surface of the water after the elemental is destroyed.

The shaft in the ceiling of this room is inaccessible without the help of a rope tied off to the grate at the top - if it is snapped or cut anyone at the bottom will have to find an alternative route back up.

The door to the north of this room is unlocked and leads to the book shop basement (area K). The door to the south is protected by a magic ward, opening only to members of the defunct cult of Telerus that used to occupy this area, which was led by the book shop owner. The door bears the mark of Telerus (cupped hands holding a flame) and has a 2 inch depression in the middle of the symbol. Inserting a signet of Telerus will suppress the spell.
A Religion check will reveal this about the cult of Telerus:

p.i: the cult was once a widespread religion centered around the planar deity Telerus, the flamebringer. Telerus was worshipped as a god of heat, light and prosperity. The religion was practiced among the non-Fey as well as Elves. It was banned during the early years of the Dominion. The symbol of the faith was a pair of cupped hands holding a burning flame. The cult promoted harmony among the different races and a communal agrarian lifestyle. Their primary holiday was on the winter solstice, when worshippers would perform fire dances to bring the return of the sun.

After being banned, some devotees of the faith continued to worship in secret. The faith remained in practice in small circles but has been all but eradicated by Dominion inquisitions. Anyone found to be worshipping Telerus inside the Dominion is sentenced to a lifetime of hard labor in state-operated work camps.

Disciples of Telerus held artifacts of the god that were imbued with solar energy in the form of heat, smoke and flame. They often employed fire elementals as servants to their causes, and were masters of incendiary magic.

The air in this room smells musty, as if it hasn’t been stirred in quite a long time, and the walls are painted with a motif of dancing flames and handprints. The room is outfitted with a long wooden table and two sturdy wooden benches. On the wall, a rack of long linen cloaks are hung, dyed a deep orange hue and emblazoned with a hand holding a flame. In the corner, an automaton man sits completely still.

text.p: This room used to serve as a cloak and guard room for the cult of Telerus. A bag of 1d30 GP worth of coins is on the table, as well as some old dirty dishes and a wineskin.

In the corner of the room sitting on the far bench is an antique security golem. It is constructed from wood, metal and ceramic components and has the symbol of Telerus scribed on its chest. Currently, its red energem power source is completely dead, and it cannot turn on or function until it is recharged or else replaced with a new one. Once running the golem acts as a guard for the entire sub basement, patrolling the area. Anyone not wearing the cloak or signet of Telerus it designates as a threat and proceeds to engage in combat with. A magic caster of sufficient skill could attempt to reprogram the energem to give it new directives. Follow the guidelines for energem impressions for more information on reprogramming it.

p.i: This room features a lofty wooden ceiling and a set of stone stairs leading up to a ladder, which ascends to a trap door. Along the walls are inset bookshelves that run all the way up, set with row upon row of dusty books and scrolls.

text.p: This area is the basement of an Elven book shop. The room is 30 feet tall, and the floor-to-ceiling bookshelves are lined with the backstock of the shop on the surface above.

After finding this area via the sewers, the kobolds have secured the route for their smuggling operation. At the time the party enters the room, three winged kobolds named Pree, Ritt, and Rika are in the area. They are significantly better organized than the kobolds in area D and will coordinate their efforts to attack the party. Once one of them becomes bloodied, one or more of them will attempt to flee to area L to inform the kobold mother and other smugglers there. The Kobolds will use the upper shelves in the room as perches, tossing heavy books as thrown weapons.

There are countless old books and scrolls in this room on all sorts of topics. If someone takes an hour to peruse they can find a book on almost any subject. There is a 1D10 chance of them finding a random scroll of 1d4 levels.

A DC15 Investigation Check will uncover a hollowed out book marked with the symbol of Telerus. Inside the book is a signet of Telerus, a small medallion in the shape of a sun with cupped hands holding a flame.

At the top of the 10 foot high set of stairs against the north wall of the room is a ladder that climbs an additional 30 feet into a shaft in the ceiling, ending at a heavy wooden trap door that has been secured by the kobolds with a large metal padlock (DC 25 to pick). Hikara holds the only key to it.

p.i: The vaulted stone roof of this room is painted with marbled red and black, evoking flame and smoke. Two massive columns flanked by stone galleries support it on either side of the entrance. In the center of the room, a lower area seems to have been flooded, and murky water now pools here. At the far end of the space rises a dias, upon which a large stone statue of a figure in a hooded cloak stands facing the entrance. A makeshift wooden causeway has been built between the entrance and the dias. The room reeks of mildew and kobolds.

text.p: This room used to be a secret shrine to Telerus, but has now become a base of operations for the Kobold clan that is smuggling through the book shop. Hikara, the Kobold Mother acting as the clans matriarch, uses the space as a lair and keeps her guards here. Brynn Belana, the granddaughter of the bookshop owner, is locked in a wooden cage next to the statue. Hikara has been keeping her hostage to act as collateral for their continued secrecy.

The room is split into north, south and west sections with the center of the room filled with 5 foot deep water. The north and south sections are used by the guards to launch ranged attacks at any intruders who attempt to enter the room. The Kobold Mother stays with the hostage in the west section. She will use Brynn as a shield against ranged attacks, and if cornered she will threaten to hurt the girl unless allowed to escape.

Hikara is significantly craftier and more intelligent than her offspring, and has been coordinating the sales of their contraband to the merchant Quell. She intends to meet him the next night to handle the sale of the basilisk blood shipment in area E.

Brynn has been locked in the cage in this room for several weeks, after having been kidnapped from her grandfather’s bookstore above. She is filthy and unkempt. She is 8 years old, and still has the elongated ears of an early stage nymph. Upon seeing the party she will call out desperately for help. If freed from the cage she will stick closely to whoever is helping her, and will beg them to take her back to her grandfather.
Next to Brynn's cage is a stash box containing Hikara's loot.

The Kobolds have built a makeshift wooden walkway to span the flooded section of the room. However, the structure is poorly built and is coming apart, with several of the boards only balancing in place. Attempting to walk or stand on the left half of the structure requires a DC15 acrobatics check in order to avoid falling into the sewer water below.
A crocodile lives in the murky water under the bridge (DC 15 perception to notice when not moving). Anyone who falls off the bridge into the water will provoke it to attack.

This statue of Telerus stands 12 feet tall at the top of a stepped dias that rises an additional 3 feet above the floor. The hands and upper portion of the statue are stained with soot from the rituals the cult used to perform here. Starting a fire in the cupped hands of the statue will cause the false wall behind it to move aside.

This wall is non-magic and made of the same material as the rest of the walls in the area. There are no markings to indicate a passage, and the Kobolds have not discovered that it hides a secret passage. A DC20 investigation will reveal minor scuffs on the floor and a thin crack to indicate that it moves.

p.i: The end for this dark flagstoned corridor opens into an octagonal room with two large stone statues appearing as armored knights. They face the center of the room, where a reinforced metal chest is bolted to the floor. The front of the chest is painted with cupped hands holding flame.

text.p: This hidden shrine holds relics of Telerus. Inside the metal chest are wooden cases containing a circlet of blasting, an eversmoking bottle, and three captured fire elementals in gems. In the case that someone not wearing a cloak of Telerus attempts to touch or open the reliquary, the two guardian statues in the room will shoot intersecting jets of flame in the square in front of the chest.

description.p: Scrap mechanical pieces that can be used by a tinker to craft devices.
Magic weapons are unmistakably finer in quality than their ordinary counterparts. You have a +1 bonus to the attack rolls and damage rolls you make with this weapon.

Mageforged weapons are crafted in a way that allows them to store a spell. A magic caster can impart any prepared attack spell on the weapon, expending one of their spell slots to transfer the spell to the weapon. The spell can then be used at the owner’s will as an effect of a melee attack. Any damage and conditions of the spell stack with the weapon damage. Once an imparted spell is used it is removed from the weapon. Only one spell can be stored at a time.
Rusted weapons suffer a penalty of -1 to attack and damage rolls. A rusted weapon can be repaired to good condition by a blacksmith or anyone proficient with smith's tools.
Magic weapons are unmistakably finer in quality than their ordinary counterparts. You have a +1 bonus to the attack rolls and damage rolls you make with this weapon.
When you roll a 20 on your attack roll with this magic weapon, your critical hit deals an extra 7 damage of the weapon's type.
Green slime contained in a crude clay pot that holds 1 pint.

As an action, you can empty this pot onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw it up to 20 feet, shattering on impact. Make a ranged attack against a target creature or object, treating as an improvized weapon. On a hit, the target is covered in a patch of green slime. Miss: A patch of green slime covers a randomly determined 5-foot-square section of wall or floor within 5 feet of the target.
You can also empty this pot on the ground to cover a 5-foot-square area, provided that the surface is level.
Rot grub larvae mixed with dessicated flesh bits in a crude clay pot that holds 1 pint.

As an action, you can empty this pot onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw it up to 20 feet, shattering on impact. Make a ranged attack against a target creature or object, treating as an improvized weapon. On a hit, the target is covered in a swarm of rot grubs. Miss: A swarm of rot grubs covers a randomly determined 5-foot-square section of wall or floor within 5 feet of the target.
You can also empty this pot on the ground to cover a 5-foot-square area, provided that the surface is level.
This earring is made of Pewter and has an ornament in the shape of a tiny bell on it. When worn, it grants a +4 to perception checks related to hearing.
Oil or spirits contained in a clay flask that holds 1 pint. When you use it, you can specify whether or not the cloth stopper is lit (requires ignition source).

As an action, you can splash this flask onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw it up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact. Make a ranged attack against a target creature or object, treating as an improvised weapon. On a hit, the target is covered. If the target takes any fire damage before it dries (after 1 minute), the target takes an additional 5 fire damage. Miss: A patch of flammable liquid covers a randomly determined 5-foot-square section of wall or floor within 5 feet of the target.

You can also empty this flask on the ground to cover a 5-foot-square area, provided that the surface is level. If lit, it burns for 2 rounds and deals 5 fire damage to any creature that enters the area or ends its turn in the area. A creature can take this damage only once per turn.
A powerful sedative. Often used to numb pain for surgery, it is extremely popular recreationally as well due to its addictive nature.

One dose completely removes all sensation of pain in the body, as well as creating a euphoric emotion in the user. It grants 1d6 temporary hit points and the user temporarily immune to being fatigued, frightened, petrified, paralyzed, stunned or exhausted.

After taking a dose, the user can move and act normally for another hour, enduring even debilitating pain. Afterwards they proceed to fall into a deep sleep for the following 4 hours, during which time it is almost impossible to wake them.

Every time a user takes this drug they run a 1d4 risk of becoming addicted. If a dose of Basilisk Blood isn't consumed once per day by an addict, they are afflicted with level 3 exhaustion (Disadvantage on ability checks, speed halved, disadvantage on attack rolls and saving throws). An addiction can only be cured via magical means.
Each vial contains three doses.

Resembling a large inside-out geode of clear crystal, this spherical structure houses the sapient energy of a water elemental. When kept in a dry environment it remains inert, however it will reanimate as a water weird once placed in contact with a body of water.

Mageforged weapons are crafted in a way that allows them to store a spell. A magic caster can impart any prepared attack spell on the weapon, expending one of their spell slots to transfer the spell to the weapon. The spell can then be used at the owner’s will as an effect of a melee attack. Any damage and conditions of the spell stack with the weapon damage. Once an imparted spell is used it is removed from the weapon. Only one spell can be stored at a time.
Rusted weapons suffer a penalty of -1 to attack and damage rolls. A rusted weapon can be repaired to good condition by a blacksmith or anyone proficient with smith's tools.

id-00001.desc:
Level: 1
School: Divination
Casting Time: 1 minute
Components: V, S, M (a pearl worth at least 100 gp and an owl feather)
Duration: Instantaneous
Range: Touch

You choose one object that you must touch throughout the casting of the spell. If it is a magic item or some other magic-imbued object, you learn its properties and how to use them, whether it requires attunement to use, and how many charges it has, if any. You learn whether any spells are affecting the item and what they are. If the item was created by a spell, you learn which spell created it.

If you instead touch a creature throughout the casting, you learn what spells, if any, are currently affecting it.
id-00001.name: Identify - 1st level

text.p: Sculpted from clay, this bulky golem stands head and shoulders taller than most human-sized creatures. It is human shaped, but its proportions are off.

Clay golems are often divinely endowed with purpose by priests of great faith. However, clay is a weak vessel for life force. If the golem is damaged, the elemental spirit bound into it can break free. Such a golem runs amok, smashing everything around it until it is destroyed or completely repaired.

Golems are made from humble materials-clay, flesh and bones, iron, or stone-but they possess astonishing power and durability. A golem has no ambitions, needs no sustenance, feels no pain, and knows no remorse. An unstoppable juggernaut, it exists to follow its creator's orders, and it protects or attacks as that creator demands.

To create a golem, one requires a manual of golems (see the Dungeon Master's Guide). The comprehensive illustrations and instructions in a manual detail the process for creating a golem of a particular type.

Elemental Spirit in Material Form. The construction of a golem begins with the building of its body, requiring great command of the craft of sculpting, stonecutting, ironworking, or surgery. Sometimes a golem's creator is the master of the art, but often the individual who desires a golem must enlist master artisans to do the work.

After constructing the body from clay, flesh, iron, or stone, the golem's creator infuses it with a spirit from the Elemental Plane of Earth. This tiny spark of life has no memory, personality, or history. It is simply the impetus to move and obey. This process binds the spirit to the artificial body and subjects it to the will of the golem's creator.

Ageless Guardians. Golems can guard sacred sites, tombs, and treasure vaults long after the deaths of their creators, carrying out their appointed tasks for all eternity while brushing off physical damage and ignoring all but the most potent spells.
A golem can be created with a special amulet or other item that allows the possessor of the item to control the golem. Golems whose creators are long dead can thus be harnessed to serve a new master.

Blind Obedience. When its creator or possessor is on hand to command it, a golem performs flawlessly. If the golem is left without instructions or is incapacitated, it continues to follow its last orders to the best of its ability. When it can't fulfill its orders, a golem might react violently-or stand and do nothing. A golem that has been given conflicting orders sometimes alternates between them.
A golem can't think or act for itself. Though it understands its commands perfectly, it has no grasp of language beyond that understanding, and can't be reasoned with or tricked with words.
Constructed Nature. A golem doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

id-00002.desc: Whenever the golem starts its turn with 30 hit points or fewer, roll a d6. On a 6, the golem goes berserk. On each of its turns while berserk, the golem attacks the nearest creature it can see. If no creature is near enough to move to and attack, the golem attacks an object, with preference for an object smaller than itself. Once the golem goes berserk, it continues to do so until it is destroyed or regains all its hit points.
id-00002.name: Berserk

id-00003.desc: The golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.
id-00003.name: Immutable Form

id-00004.desc: The golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.
id-00004.name: Magic Resistance

id-00005.desc: The golem's weapon attacks are magical.
id-00005.name: Magic Weapons

description.p: For your first mission, the Resistance has tasked you with finding and securing a smuggler's route under the Drostella border wall. It is rumored the entrance is somewhere near the tavern known as The Grinning Gander.
Scrap mechanical pieces that can be used by a tinker to craft devices.
Green slime contained in a crude clay pot that holds 1 pint.

As an action, you can empty this pot onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw it up to 20 feet, shattering on impact. Make a ranged attack against a target creature or object, treating as an improvized weapon. On a hit, the target is covered in a patch of green slime. Miss: A patch of green slime covers a randomly determined 5-foot-square section of wall or floor within 5 feet of the target.
You can also empty this pot on the ground to cover a 5-foot-square area, provided that the surface is level.
Rot grub larvae mixed with dessicated flesh bits in a crude clay pot that holds 1 pint.

As an action, you can empty this pot onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw it up to 20 feet, shattering on impact. Make a ranged attack against a target creature or object, treating as an improvized weapon. On a hit, the target is covered in a swarm of rot grubs. Miss: A swarm of rot grubs covers a randomly determined 5-foot-square section of wall or floor within 5 feet of the target.
You can also empty this pot on the ground to cover a 5-foot-square area, provided that the surface is level.
For 1 hour, a candle sheds bright light in a 5-foot radius and dim light for an additional 5 feet.

Oil usually comes in a clay flask that holds 1 pint. As an action, you can splash the oil in this flask onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw it up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact. Make a ranged attack against a target creature or object, treating the oil as an improvised weapon. On a hit, the target is covered in oil. If the target takes any fire damage before the oil dries (after 1 minute), the target takes an additional 5 fire damage from the burning oil. You can also pour a flask of oil on the ground to cover a 5-foot-square area, provided that the surface is level. If lit, the oil burns for 2 rounds and deals 5 fire damage to any creature that enters the area or ends its turn in the area. A creature can take this damage only once per turn.
This gemstone is opaque light pink in color.
This gemstone is opaque light and dark blue with yellow flecks in color.
This gemstone is opaque gray-black in color.
This gemstone is opaque mottled deep blue in color.
Magic weapons are unmistakably finer in quality than their ordinary counterparts. You have a +1 bonus to the attack rolls and damage rolls you make with this weapon.

Mageforged weapons are crafted in a way that allows them to store a spell. A magic caster can impart any prepared attack spell on the weapon, expending one of their spell slots to transfer the spell to the weapon. The spell can then be used at the owner’s will as an effect of a melee attack. Any damage and conditions of the spell stack with the weapon damage. Once an imparted spell is used it is removed from the weapon. Only one spell can be stored at a time.
Rusted weapons suffer a penalty of -1 to attack and damage rolls. A rusted weapon can be repaired to good condition by a blacksmith or anyone proficient with smith's tools.
This gem contains a mote of elemental energy. When you use an action to break the gem, a fire elemental is summoned as if you had cast the conjure elemental spell, and the gem's magic is lost.

id-00001.name: Red Elemental Gem
id-00001.nonidentified: A crystal clear corundum which, when you look into it, seems to contain a mote of something bright deep inside its core.

description.p: While wearing this circlet, you can use an action to cast the scorching ray spell with it. When you make the spell's attacks, you do so with an attack bonus of +5. The circlet can't be used this way again until the next dawn.

id-00002.name: Circlet of Blasting
id-00002.nonidentified: Made of gold this circlet has a stylised sun symbol set with a large cut stone at its centre.

description.p: Smoke leaks from the lead-stoppered mouth of this brass bottle, which weighs 1 pound. When you use an action to remove the stopper, a cloud of thick smoke pours out in a 60-foot radius from the bottle. The cloud's area is heavily obscured. Each minute the bottle remains open and within the cloud, the radius increases by 10 feet until it reaches its maximum radius of 120 feet.

The cloud persists as long as the bottle is open. Closing the bottle requires you to speak its command word as an action. Once the bottle is closed, the cloud disperses after 10 minutes. A moderate wind (11 to 20 miles per hour) can also disperse the smoke after 1 minute, and a strong wind (21 or more miles per hour) can do so after 1 round.

id-00003.name: Eversmoking Bottle
id-00003.nonidentified: A strangely shaped brass bottle with a leaden stopper through which a thin stream of smoke continually escapes.

description.p: As an action, a creature can light a stick of dynamite and throw it at a point up to 60 feet away. Each creature within 5 feet of that point must make a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw, taking 3d6 bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

A character can bind sticks of dynamite together so they explode at the same time. Each additional stick increases the damage by 1d6 (to a maximum of 10d6) and the burst radius by 5 feet (to a maximum of 20 feet).

Dynamite can be rigged with a longer fuse to explode after a set amount of time, usually 1 to 6 rounds. Roll initiative for the dynamite. After the set number of rounds goes by, the dynamite explodes on that initiative.
A character who drinks the magical red fluid in this vial regains 2d4 + 2 hit points. Drinking or administering a potion takes an action.
